MathException Class Reference

The class MathException provides methods for handling run-time errors and exceptions in mathematical operations that use the functions of the matrix library. More...

#include <MathException.hpp>

List of all members.

void setErrorTypeIncompatibleSize ()
void setErrorTypeTypeMismatch ()

Detailed Description

The class MathException provides methods for handling run-time errors and exceptions in mathematical operations that use the functions of the matrix library.

Example Program: 

//========================================================================
// Project: Robotic Platform
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------
// Package      : The Math Library
// Authors      : Vilas Kumar Chitrakaran
// Start Date   : Wed Dec 20 11:08:28 GMT 2000
// Compiler     : GNU c++
// Operating System : QNX RTP
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------
// File: MathException.t.cpp
// Example program for the class MathExceptions.
//========================================================================  
 

// ----- Standard Libaries -----
#include <iostream.h>

// ----- Project Includes -----
#include "Matrix.hpp"
#include "ColumnVector.hpp"
#include "RowVector.hpp"

//======================================================================== 
// main
//========================================================================  
 
int main()
{

  Matrix<4,3> M1;
  Matrix<3,4> M2;
  Matrix<3,3> M3;
  MatrixBase<> &RefM1 = M1;
  MatrixBase<> &RefM2 = M2;

  ColumnVector<4> C1;
  ColumnVector<3> C2;
  VectorBase<> &RefC1 = C1;
  VectorBase<> &RefC2 = C2;


  RowVector<3> R1;
  RowVector<4> R2;
  VectorBase<> &RefR1 = R1;
  VectorBase<> &RefR2 = R2;

//---------------------------------------------------------------------------
// Each of the following operations will raise a MathException. The following
// lines of code show how to handle exceptions caused by illegal operations
// in the MathLibrary.
//---------------------------------------------------------------------------

// Assignment between two Matrix objects of different dimensions.
  try{
  M1 = M2;
  }
  catch(MathException ex)
  {
    cout << "M1 = M2: " << ex.getErrorMessage() << endl;
  }

// Assignment between a reference to MatrixBase object and a Matrix object of different dimensions.
  try{
  //M1 = RefM2;
  RefM1 = M2;
  }
  catch(MathException ex)
  {
    cout << "M1 = RefM2 or RefM1 = M2: " << ex.getErrorMessage() << endl;
  }

// Assignment between two references to MatrixBase objects of different dimensions.
  try{
  RefM1 = RefM2;
  }
  catch(MathException ex)
  {
    cout << "RefM1 = RefM2: " << ex.getErrorMessage() << endl;
  }

// Assignment between two references to VectorBase objects of different dimensions.
  try{
  RefR1 = RefR2;
  }
  catch(MathException ex)
  {
    cout << "RefR1 = RefR2: " << ex.getErrorMessage() << endl;
  }

// Assignment between a VectorBase reference and a Vector of a different size but same type.
  try{
  //RefR1 = R2; // Each one of these will raise exceptions.
  R2 = RefR1;
  }
  catch(MathException ex)
  {
    cout << "R2 = RefR1 or RefR1 = R2: " << ex.getErrorMessage() << endl;
  }

// Assignment between two ColumnVector objects of different dimensions.
  try{
  C1 = C2;
  }
  catch(MathException ex)
  {
    cout <<"C1 = C2: " << ex.getErrorMessage() << endl;
  }

// Assignment between two RowVector objects of different dimensions.
  try{
  R1 = R2;
  }
  catch(MathException ex)
  {
    cout << "R1 = R2: " << ex.getErrorMessage() << endl;
  }

// Assignment between a VectorBase object referenced to a ColumnVector and another ColumnVector object of different dimensions.
  try{
  C1 = RefC2;
  }
  catch(MathException ex)
  {
    cout << "C1 = RefC2: " << ex.getErrorMessage() << endl;
  }

// Assignment between a VectorBase object referenced to a ColumnVector and another ColumnVector object of different dimensions.
  try{
  R1 = RefR2;
  }
  catch(MathException ex)
  {
    cout << "R1 = RefR2: " << ex.getErrorMessage() << endl;
  }

// Assignment between two VectorBase references, one pointing to a RowVector and other to a ColumnVector.
  try{
  RefR2 = RefC2;
  }
  catch(MathException ex)
  {
    cout << "RefR2 = RefC2: " << ex.getErrorMessage() << endl;
  }

// Assignment between a VectorBase reference and a Vector of a different type (column/row).
  try{
  RefR2 = C2; // Each one of these will raise exceptions.
  //C1 = RefR1;
  }
  catch(MathException ex)
  {
    cout << "C1 = RefR1 or RefR2 = C2: " << ex.getErrorMessage() << endl;
  }

// Assignment between a RowVector and a ColumnVector.
  try{
  R1 = C2;
  }
  catch(MathException ex)
  {
    cout << "R1 = C2: " << ex.getErrorMessage() << endl;
  }


// Indexing beyond the range of a non-scalar object.
// Each of the following will cause exceptions.
  double scalar;
  try{
  scalar = M1(5,5);
  //scalar = C1(6);
  //scalar = R1(6);
  }
  catch(MathException ex)
  {
    cout << ex.getErrorMessage() << endl;
  }

// Trying to find inverse of a singular matrix.
  try{
  inverse(M3);
  }
  catch(MathException ex)
  {
    cout << "inverse(M3): "<< ex.getErrorMessage() << endl;
  }

// Trying to divide a non-scalar type by zero.
  try{
  M1/0.0;
  }
  catch(MathException ex)
  {
    cout <<"M1/0.0: " << ex.getErrorMessage() << endl;
  }

// Trying to extract/fit a sub-matrix of improper dimensions from/to a matrix.

  Matrix<2,2> subMatrix;
  try{
  M1.setSubMatrix(3,3,subMatrix); // The subMatrix does not fit into the matrix.
  }    
  catch(MathException ex)
  {
    cout <<"M1.setSubMatrix(3,3,subMatrix): " << ex.getErrorMessage() << endl;
  }
  try{
  M1.getSubMatrix(3,3,subMatrix); // The subMatrix does not fit into the matrix.
  }    
  catch(MathException ex)
  {
    cout <<"M1.getSubMatrix(3,3,subMatrix): " << ex.getErrorMessage() << endl;
  }

// The functions \a isErrorType..() can be used to determine the type of
// of error that caused the exception. For exxample, lets try the divide by 
// zero exception again...

  try{
  M1/0.0;
  }
  catch(MathException ex)
  {
    if(ex.isErrorTypeSingularMatrix())
      cout << "I want to do THIS for singular matrix exceptions." << endl;
    if(ex.isErrorTypeDivideByZero())
      cout << "I'm gonna do anything for you, but I won't do THAT." << endl;
    cout <<"M1/0.0: " << ex.getErrorMessage() << endl;
  }

return 0;
}

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

MathException ( ) [inline]
 

The default constructor.

~MathException ( ) [inline]
 

The Default Destructor

Member Function Documentation

Sets the exception type to e_exSingularMatrix.
